info.game_comments: (Sarah: Jeopardy! will get your mind and your body in shape--coming up next.)

(1, 1).clue: The issue is dated March 3, 1923 & this president is the first person mentioned in it

(2, 1).clue: Nothing proverbs include "Nothing have, nothing crave" & "Nothing ventured, nothing" this

(3, 1).clue: Bill Cosby knows that this dessert brand is a mix of sugar, fruit flavoring & gelatin

(4, 1).clue: The Random House word menu dates scratching, synthpop & new age back to this decade

(5, 1).clue: A drill instructor who shouts "Drop and give me twenty!" means twenty of these

(1, 2).clue: With more slapstick than "The Kid", this man's new film "The Pilgrim" was a "funny example of custard-piety"

(2, 2).clue: Jewish actor John Banner played Rudolf Hess as well as this "I know nothing!" TV sergeant

(3, 2).clue: Voiced by Cosby, this not-exactly-svelte character was known for his catchphrase, "Hey, Hey, Hey!"

(4, 2).clue: The large orchestras in the swing era were dubbed with this alliterative name

(5, 2).clue: In the step type of this form of exercise a platform can be raised to make you work harder

(1, 3).clue: Mon dieu! Prof. Charles Henri can speed up this process in new wine with a 60,000 volt electrostatic field

(2, 3).clue: This "medical" artist released the 1993 hit "Nuthin' But a 'G' Thang"

(3, 3).clue: Cosby produced "Men of Honor", about Navy diver Carl Brashear, starring this "Jerry Maguire" Oscar winner

(4, 3).clue: "Everybody's talkin' 'bout the new sound, funny, but it's still" this to Billy Joel

(5, 3).clue: (Sarah of the Clue Crew exercises on an exercise bike.) Referring to exercise that raises your heart rate and gets your blood flowing, "cardio" is short for this.

(1, 4).clue: A column suggested this "mythical" James Joyce novel was written by picking words at random from a hat

(2, 4).clue: Shakespeare play that features the bumbling policeman named Dogberry

(3, 4).clue: On this "cloak & dagger" '60s show, Bill played Tempe grad & Rhodes Scholar Alexander Scott

(4, 4).clue: Kenny Vance & the Planotones are out there performing in this '50s vocal style

(5, 4).clue: It sounds like what Simon of Cyrene did in the Gospels, but it means varying your activities for all-around fitness

(1, 5).clue: Obits included Thomas Shaw, last survivor of this hard-charging British military group, subject of a famous poem

(2, 5).clue: Something that's no big deal is described in this phrase; we presume it also covers a boring e-mail to mom

(4, 5).clue: Reggae came out of Jamaica; this popular '50s style came from a samba-like style of Trinidad

(5, 5).clue: It's the "electrical" term for the amount of weight or pressure involved in an exercise

(1, 1).clue: A barbecue takes place at Twelve Oaks, the Wilkes family plantation, in chapter VI of this novel

(2, 1).clue: He made his Hollywood debut with "Rosemary's Baby" the same year he married Sharon Tate

(4, 1).clue: It's the act of occupying a building as a form of protest

(5, 1).clue: It's the "numerical" bar where you can relax & have a drink after a round of golf

(6, 1).clue: WWII's Battle of the Coral Sea was the first naval battle in which these, not the ships, did the attacking

(1, 2).clue: (Sofia of the Clue Crew ascends a staircase.) I'm here on the hidden staircase in this mysterious house that inspired a Nathaniel Hawthorne novel.

(2, 2).clue: He passed away in 1999 just months before the release of his final film, "Eyes Wide Shut"

(4, 2).clue: After the Battle of the Little Bighorn, this leader stood up & escaped to Canada

(5, 2).clue: These tissues that may be smooth or skeletal countract & relax, thereby producing the movement of body parts

(6, 2).clue: By flooding it, large mock naval battles were often held in this largest Roman amphitheater

(1, 3).clue: In a Thomas Love Peacock novel, Headlong Hall is Squire Headlong's country home in this U.K. principality

(2, 3).clue: Last name of Jonathan, who directed "Philadelphia" & nephew Ted, who directed "Blow"

(3, 3).clue: In Nevada: "The Biggest Little City in the World"

(4, 3).clue: The name of this instrument is from the Hindi for "3-stringed", though it has more

(5, 3).clue: You can relax & enjoy the 47 thermal bodies of water at this Arkansas national park

(6, 3).clue: After losing more than 60 ships in the summer of 1588, this Spanish fleet limped home in defeat

(1, 4).clue: Mr. Lockwood becomes Mr. Heathcliff's tenant at Thrushcross Grange in chapter 1 of this novel

(2, 4).clue: Czech out "One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest" & "The People vs. Larry Flynt"; he directed both

(4, 4).clue: Last name of Dame Edith, known for her poem "Still Falls the Rain"

(5, 4).clue: From the French for "relax", it was the relaxation of Cold War tensions between the U.S. & the U.S.S.R.

(6, 4).clue: The British lost no ships & the French about 20 when their naval forces clashed in this 1805 battle near Cadiz, Spain

(1, 5).clue: In a novel by Sir Walter Scott, this title character & his father Cedric are held captive in Torquilstone Castle

(2, 5).clue: This director of "He Got Game" has the real first name of Shelton

(4, 5).clue: It's not the larch. It's the variety of spruceseen here.

(5, 5).clue: "Art raises its head when religions relax their hold", once remarked this ubermensch philosopher

(6, 5).clue: In one of the largest naval battles ever, over 250 ships took part in the 1916 battle off this Danish peninsula

(0, 0).clue: This pro sports team has 3 official mascots: Edgar, Allan & Poe
